author: timbeiko
content:
I used to agree with this fairly strongly, but I think we‚Äôve recently reached a tipping point where the downsides of informal approaches outweigh the benefits from them. My sense is many of our recent issues, from the lack of proper incident response to Holesky‚Äôs failures and now a miscommunication around setting mainnet dates, are a consequence of informal systems not working well enough. 

This isn‚Äôt to say we should completely lean in the other direction, but we should be mindful of the failure modes of more formality and plan for them too.

author: sky.cactus

author: timbeiko
content:
To take this example, maybe it‚Äôs fine to make it a ‚Äúfull consensus‚Äù, but I don‚Äôt think this reflects the current reality. 

First, in practice delays between clients are often minimal. IIRC the largest ‚Äúdelay‚Äù we‚Äôve ever seen by a team was when shipping Berlin, where Erigon was a couple weeks behind due to their mempool implementation. We put out the blog post with a ‚ÄúTBA‚Äù for the version number, eventually updated it, and it was fine. 

To be clear, this isn‚Äôt to say Erigon did anything wrong. But to emphasize that the worst case I can remember was relatively minor and nothing went wrong by proceeding with the fork. 

Second, the current informal process deals with this more gracefully, IMO, than a formal one. If we say ‚Äúwe don‚Äôt schedule the fork until literally every single client is 100% ready‚Äù, that opens up a clear governance attack: create a client and just refuse to be ready, stalling everyone else. 

This example is obviously a strawman, but highlights that we need to draw a line somewhere. 

I‚Äôm very weakly opinionated about what that bar is (and, again, don‚Äôt think in practice it makes a huge difference). If we chose to do ‚Äúrough consensus over the hard fork sign up sheet‚Äù, that works for me, but we should all be on the same page about what that mean, to avoid repeating our current mistakes.

author: timbeiko
content:
Right, the complexity has grown, it does mean we need more processes, but I‚Äôm less convinced this is a clear path to capture than I used to be. 

I agree with you that ossification is the only way to avoid any risk of capture. 

IMO we should be better at delineating what parts of Ethereum should ossify vs. not. But, on the whole, Ethereum isn‚Äôt   planning to ossify in the short term.

author: timbeiko
content:
My core point is not about clients being late: it's about fixing a breakdown in process/communications/expectations. _That_ is what went wrong in Holesky incident response, and in setting a mainnet block, both because we didn't have the right inputs on the call, or a clear, shared understanding of the constraints (see Paul/Nixo's exchange earlier). 

My proposal to fix this is to include "setting the hard fork block" as part of the async process we agreed to use in ACD last week, as we also said we'd agree to set people from each client teams to monitor the fork. 

My (poorly introduced üòÖ) solution to prevent more miscommunication and failure modes of async processes is to explicitly define what our threshold should be for moving forward with a fork block. Perhaps "supermajority" is the wrong one. An alternative could be "no strong objections by teams on the latest devnet by Date X". Either is fine, but I want to avoid a situation where a team hasn't bothered to make a PR to the `.md` file and we're holding up the fork because of that üôÇ

author: timbeiko
content:
Another way to approach this, which may be less of a departure from our current process, is to default to always "Propose" a fork date on ACD{E|C} and "Confirm" it on the second call.  I think this would better convey that a date is tentative and avoid the "non-confirmation" being perceived as a delay. 

It's always ideal to have as much input as possible in the first step, but this approach would leave everyone one week to review the date and raise concerns. We could still track the `Proposed` date in the meantime, and just switch it to `Confirmed` the week after. 

If we went ahead with this, two things to figure out are:

1. If we change a date on the next ACD, do we want to wait another week to confirm? For example, if this week we go from April 30th to something else, do we  want to then re-confirm the new date on ACDE next week?

2. Where do we start the 30 day counter from? A `Proposed` date? A `Confirmed` one (If so, `Proposed` must be +37 days out).
